abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Transport Rehabilitation
            Project for Serbia were as follows: outcomes were
            satisfactory, risk to development outcome was moderate, Bank
            performance was moderately satisfactory, and Borrower
            performance was satisfactory. Some lessons learned included:
            The Borrowers or Implementing Agencies (IAs) initiative
            has a greater chance to succeed than one promoted by
            International Financial Institutions (IFIs). Public
            Enterprise Roads of Serbias (PERSs ) commitment to the
            introduction of Performance-based Contracts (PBCs) was
            critical to the early success of the intervention. When such
            ownership and commitment exists, the Bank should work
            closely to support the government. In this case, the Bank,
            together with European International Bank (EIB) and European
            Bank for Reconstruction and Development (EBRD) who have
            showed commitment to the same agenda, should continue
            helping the Government of Serbia (GOS) realize that the
            cost-effectiveness of PBCs can be achieved through: (i)
            breaking up the monopoly of regional contractors who receive
            routine maintenance contracts under traditional unit-based
            contracts without competition; and (ii) introducing more
            output-based services in the PBCs. Recommendations of road
            safety audits should be directly incorporated into the road
            designs at the earlier stages of the design process.
            Contractors should have staff specifically responsible for
            implementation and monitoring of Environmental Management
            Plans (EMPs), in order to ensure compliant environmental
            safeguards implementation. Closer collaboration with the
            ministries responsible for utilities should be achieved
            prior to the start of the civil works.

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Transport
            Rehabilitation Project is to assist the Government of Serbia
            in reducing cost and improving safety for road users
            through: a) improving the condition of selected road
            sections of the main and regional road network; b) improving
            the effectiveness of road maintenance through the
            introduction of performance-based contracting in two pilot
            regions; and c) introducing safe road design principles,
            road safety audits, and targeted improvement measures. The
            change, which was requested by the Government of the
            Republic of Serbia by letter dated June 11, 2012, consists
            of a three and a half month extension of the closing date of
            the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development
            (IBRD) loan from June 15, 2012 to September 30, 2012. The
            extension is necessary to complete the remaining civil works
            and to ensure achievement of the project's development
            objectives (PDO). This will be the third extension of the
            IBRD loan closing date, which will cumulatively bring the
            total extension period to three years and nine months and
            the total implementation period to approximately seven and a
            half years. No changes to the PDO or results framework are
            needed. Implementation agencies remain the same, there are
            no outstanding audits, financial management reports are
            satisfactory, and the project is progressing satisfactorily.
            The project's objectives continue to be achievable
            within the extended closing date period; the performance of
            the borrower and the project implementing agencies continues
            to be satisfactory. The restructuring does not involve any
            other changes. Disbursements from the loan as of June 13,
            2012 amounted to EUR 25 million, and the loan will be fully
            disbursed by the new loan closing date.

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Transport
            Rehabilitation Project is to assist the Government of Serbia
            in reducing cost and improving safety for road users
            through: a) improving the condition of selected road
            sections of the main and regional road network; b) improving
            the effectiveness of road maintenance through the
            introduction of performance-based contracting in two pilot
            regions; and c) introducing safe road design principles,
            road safety audits, and targeted improvement measures. The
            project restructuring is needed to extend the project
            closing date following a request from the Government of the
            Republic of Serbia received in a letter dated October 10,
            2011. With the restructuring, the project closing date will
            be extended from December 31, 2011 to June 15, 2012. The
            restructuring does not involve any other changes.

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Transport
            Rehabilitation Project is to assist the Government of Serbia
            in reducing cost and improving safety for road users
            through: (a) improving the condition of selected road
            sections of the main and regional road network; (b)
            improving the effectiveness of road maintenance through the
            introduction of performance-based contracting in two pilot
            regions; and (c) introducing safe road design principles,
            road safety audits, and targeted improvement measures. A
            retroactive increase in the disbursement percentages for
            categories works, goods, and consultants services in
            schedule one, part two of the credit agreement from 91
            percent, 90 percent and 80 percent respectively to 100
            percent for all eligible payments. This change is to be
            introduced for all eligible payments for the years 2009,
            2010, and 2011. The disbursement percentages are completely
            within the approved country financing parameters for Serbia.
